Please see the talk page about this. Also, Welsh born does not belong in the lead as per Wikipedia guidelines. --> {{Infobox person | image =ChristianBaleJun09.jpg | alt = Christian Bale in a black suit at a movie premiere. | caption=Bale in June 2009 | birth_name = Christian Charles Philip Bale | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|1|30|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Haverfordwest]], Pembrokeshire, Wales, [[United Kingdom]]<ref name="Wills" /> | occupation = Actor | years_active = 1982âpresent | spouse = Sandra BlaÅ¾iÄ (2000âpresent; 1 daughter) }} '''Christian Charles Philip Bale''' (born 30 January 1974) is an<!--this is not where awards go--> English<!--Do not change Bale's Nationality without consensus--> actor.<ref name="NotWelsh">{{cite web|url=http://www.christianbale.net/articles/2000/imdb2000.htm|quote =I was born in Wales but I'm not Welsh â I'm English|title=Christian Bale: American Psycho|publisher=IMDB News|accessdate=21 July 2008}}</ref> Best known for his roles in American films, Bale has starred in both big budget Hollywood films and the smaller projects from [[independent film|independent]] producers and [[art film|art houses]].
Bale first caught the public eye at the age of 13, when he was cast in the starring role of [[Steven Spielberg]]'s ''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]'' (1987). He played an English boy who is separated from his parents and subsequently finds himself lost in a [[List of concentration and internment camps#Japanese WWII Camps in Asia|Japanese internment camp]] during [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Singer|first=Leigh|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/film/filmblog/2009/feb/19/best-actors-never-nominated-for-oscars|title=Oscars: the best actors never to have been nominated|publisher=The Guardian|date=19 February 2009|accessdate=26 February 2010|location=London}}</ref> He is also notable for his role as [[serial killer]] [[Patrick Bateman]] in ''[[American Psycho (film)|American Psycho]]'' (2000), and for portraying [[Batman|Bruce Wayne/Batman]] in [[Christopher Nolan]]'s ''[[Batman Begins]]'' (2005) and ''[[The Dark Knight (film)|The Dark Knight]]'' (2008).
In 2010, Bale portrayed [[Dicky Eklund]] in the biopic ''[[The Fighter (2010 film)|The Fighter]]''. He received critical acclaim for his role and won several awards, including the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]], the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor - Motion Picture|Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor]] and the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Supporting Role]].
==Early life== Bale was born in [[Wales]] to parents of English descent. His South Africanâborn father, [[David Bale]], was an entrepreneur, commercial pilot, and talent manager, and his mother, Jenny James, was a circus performer.<ref>[http://www.filmreference.com/film/91/Christian-Bale.html "Christian Bale Biography (1974â)."] FilmReference.com.</ref><ref name="rourke">{{cite news |first=Mary |last=Rourke |title=Activist David Bale had commitment to Africa |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2001829381_baleobit04.html |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=4 January 2004 |accessdate=30 June 2008}}</ref><ref name="zielbauer">{{cite news |first=Paul |last=von Zielbauer |title=David Bale, 62, Activist and Businessman, Dies |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/01/national/01BALE.html?ex=1388379600&en=af5fe14869777fca&ei=5007&partner=USERLAND |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=1 January 2004 |accessdate=30 June 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name=Eonl>{{cite news|last=Serpe|first=Gina|title=Christian Bailed Over Alleged Assault; Denies Wrongdoing|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/christian_bailed_over_alleged_assault/3340|accessdate=26 September 2011|newspaper=EOnline.com|date=22 July, 2008}}</ref> He is the youngest of four children. After leaving Britain at the age of 2 in 1976, Bale spent his childhood in several countries, such as [[Portugal]].<ref name="Wills" />
Settling for four years in [[Bournemouth]] and [[Henley-on-Thames]], Bale was educated at Shiplake Church of England Primary School, the independent [[Dolphin School (Berkshire)|Dolphin School, Berkshire]], and at [[Bournemouth School]]. He played [[rugby football|rugby]].<ref name="Wills" /> Bale has described his childhood, with respect to his mother being in the circus, as "interesting."{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} He recalled his first kiss was with an [[acrobatics|acrobat]] named Barta.<ref name="Wills" />
As a child, he trained in ballet and guitar.<ref name="Wills" /> His sister Louise's work in theatre also influenced his decision to become an actor.<ref name="Wills" /> Bale's father was very supportive of his son's acting, resigning from his job as a commercial pilot to travel and manage Bale's burgeoning career.<ref name="Wills"/> The elder Bale later married feminist icon [[Gloria Steinem]].<ref name="Broughton" /> He died, at age 62, on 30 December 2003 from [[lymphoma|brain lymphoma]].<ref name="zielbauer"/>
Bale's first foray into acting was a commercial for the fabric softener [[Lenor]] in 1982, when he was 8 years old.<ref name="Hotdog">[http://www.christianbale.net/articles/2005/hotdog2005.htm "Batman Begins."]{{dead link|date=February 2010}} ''Christian Bale â An Unofficial Appreciation'', March 2005, retrieved on 15 May 2006.</ref> A year later, he appeared in a ''[[Pac-Man]]'' cereal commercial playing a child [[wikt:rockstar|rock star]]. In 1984, he made his stage debut in ''[[The Nerd]]'', opposite [[Rowan Atkinson]].<ref>Kamarauskas, K. [http://www.thespiannet.com/actors/B/bale_christian/index.shtml Christian Bale profile at Thespian Net]</ref>
==Career== ===1986â1998=== [[File:Ch Bale 02.jpg|upright|thumb|alt=Black and white photograph of Christian Bale|A 14-year-old Bale in [[Stockholm]], Sweden in February 1988 while promoting ''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]]]
Bale made his film debut as [[Tsarevich Alexei Nikolaevich of Russia]] in the made-for-television film ''[[Anastasia: The Mystery of Anna]]'' in 1986, which was followed by leading roles in the miniseries ''Heart of the Country'' and the fantasy adventure ''[[Mio in the Land of Faraway]]'', in which he appeared with [[Christopher Lee]] and [[Nick Pickard]].
In 1987, [[Amy Irving]], his co-star in ''Anastasia: The Mystery of Anna'', recommended Bale to her then-husband, [[Steven Spielberg]], for a role in ''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]'', adapted from the [[J.G. Ballard]] semi-autobiography.<ref name="Wills">Wills, Dominic. [http://www.tiscali.co.uk/entertainment/film/biographies/christian_bale_biog.html "Christian Bale Biography"] [[Tiscali SpA|Tiscali.co.uk]], retrieved on 17 May 2006.</ref> Bale's performance as Jim Graham earned him widespread critical praise and the first ever "Best Performance by a Juvenile Actor" award from the [[National Board of Review of Motion Pictures]].<ref name="bbc wales">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/arts/sites/themes/film/christian_bale.shtml|title=BBC Wales â Arts â Christian Bale|work=[[BBC Wales]]|publisher=BBC|accessdate=13 April 2009}}</ref> The attention the press and his schoolmates lavished upon him after this took a toll on Bale, and he contemplated giving up acting until [[Kenneth Branagh]] approached him and persuaded him to appear in ''[[Henry V (1989 film)|Henry V]]'' in 1989.<ref name="bbc wales" /> In 1990, he played the role of [[Jim Hawkins (character)|Jim Hawkins]] opposite [[Charlton Heston]] (as [[Long John Silver]]) in ''[[Treasure Island (1990 film)|Treasure Island]]'', an adaptation of [[Robert Louis Stevenson]]'s [[Treasure Island|classic book]].
In 1992, Bale starred as Jack Kelly in the [[Disney]] musical ''[[Newsies]]'', and followed it up in 1993 with another release, ''[[Swing Kids (film)|Swing Kids]]'', a movie about teenagers who secretly listened to forbidden [[jazz]] during the rise of [[Nazi Germany]].<ref name="cnn knight">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/07/28/christian.bale/index.html|title='Knight's' Bale: Who is that masked man?|date=28 July 2008|publisher=[[CNN|CNN: Showbiz/Movies]]|accessdate=20 April 2009}}</ref> Bale was recommended by actress [[Winona Ryder]] to star in [[Gillian Armstrong]]'s 1994 film ''[[Little Women (1994 film)|Little Women]]''.<ref name="bbc wales" /> Bale provided the voice for Thomas, a young compatriot of Captain [[John Smith (explorer)|John Smith]], in Disney's ''[[Pocahontas (1995 film)|Pocahontas]]'' (1995) and in 1997 played Arthur Stuart in ''[[Velvet Goldmine]]'', [[Todd Haynes]]' tribute to [[glam rock]].<ref name="cnn knight" /> In 1999, Bale contributed to an all-star cast, including [[Kevin Kline]], [[Michelle Pfeiffer]], [[Stanley Tucci]], and [[Rupert Everett]], portraying [[Demetrius]] in an updated version of [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream (1999 film)|A Midsummer Night's Dream]]''.<ref name="cnn knight" />
=== 1999â2001 === In 1999, Bale played serial killer [[Patrick Bateman]] in ''[[American Psycho (film)|American Psycho]]'', director [[Mary Harron]]'s adaptation of [[Bret Easton Ellis]]' [[American Psycho|controversial novel]]. Bale was briefly dropped from the project in favor of [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], but DiCaprio eventually dropped out to star in ''[[The Beach (film)|The Beach]]'', and Bale was cast once again. He researched his character by studying the novel and prepared himself physically for the role by spending months tanning and exercising in order to achieve the "[[Twelve Olympians|Olympian]] physique" of the character as described in the original novel.<ref>Fischer, Paul. [http://www.crankycritic.com/qa/pf_articles/christianbale.html "Unmasking an American Psycho."] ''The Cranky Critic'', retrieved on 15 May 2006.</ref> He went so far as to distance himself from the cast and crew to maintain the darker side of Bateman's character. ''American Psycho'' premiered at the [[Sundance Film Festival|2000 Sundance Film Festival]] to much controversy. [[Roger Ebert]] condemned the film at first, calling it pornography,<ref name="McCormick">McCormick, Moira. [http://video.barnesandnoble.com/search/interview.asp?CTR=104632 "Christian Bale â Good Christian Talks About Playing a Yuppie from Hell"] [[Barnes & Noble|Barnes & Noble.com]], 5 September 2000, retrieved on 15 May 2006.</ref> and "the most loathed film at Sundance,"<ref name="Kaufman">Kaufman, Anthony. [http://web.archive.org/web/20030224004430/http://www2.indiewire.com/people/int_Harron_Mary_000414.html "INTERVIEW: 9-Months Pregnant and Delivering "American Psycho", Director Mary Harron."] ''[[indieWIRE]]''. 14 April 2006, retrieved on 15 May 2006.</ref> but gave it a favourable review, writing that Harron "transformed a novel about bloodlust into a movie about men's vanity." Of Bale's performance, he wrote, "Christian Bale is heroic in the way he allows the character to leap joyfully into despicability; there is no instinct for self-preservation here, and that is one mark of a good actor."<ref>Ebert, Roger. [http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20000414/REVIEWS/4140303/1023 American Psycho"] ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', 14 April 2000, retrieved on 17 May 2006.</ref>
On 14 April 2000, [[Lions Gate Entertainment|Lions Gate Films]] released ''American Psycho'' in theatres. Bale was later approached to make a [[cameo appearance]] in another Bret Easton Ellis adaptation, ''[[The Rules of Attraction (film)|The Rules of Attraction]]'', a film loosely connected to ''American Psycho'', but he declined out of loyalty to Harron's vision of Bateman, which he felt could not be properly expressed by anyone else.<ref name="Morris">Morris, Clint. [http://web.archive.org/web/20071011164040/http://www.moviehole.net/news/201.html Interview: Christian Bale] ''Moviehole'', retrieved on 16 May 2006 </ref> In 2000, he again played a wealthy murderer, this time in [[John Singleton]]'s ''[[Shaft (2000 film)|Shaft]]''.
Bale has played an assortment of diverse characters since 2001. His first role after ''American Psycho'' was in the [[John Madden (director)|John Madden]] [[Captain Corelli's Mandolin (film)|adaptation]] of the best-selling novel ''[[Captain Corelli's Mandolin]]''. Bale played Mandras, a [[Greeks|Greek]] [[fisherman]] who vied with [[Nicolas Cage]]'s title character for the affections of Pelagia ([[Penelope Cruz]]). ''Captain Corelli's Mandolin'' was Bale's second time working with [[John Hurt]], after ''All the Little Animals''.
===2002â2004=== From 2002 to 2003, Bale starred in three feature films. ''[[Laurel Canyon (film)|Laurel Canyon]]'' (2002) was generally well received by critics.<ref>{{cite web|title=Laurel Canyon (2003)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/laurel_canyon|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]}}</ref> This film also marked the second time he worked with actress [[Kate Beckinsale]], his costar in ''Prince of Jutland'' (1994). Critics generally focused on star [[Frances McDormand]]'s performance over the rest of the cast, however.<ref>[http://www.metacritic.com/video/titles/laurelcanyon "Laurel Canyon."] ''[[Metacritic]]''. retrieved on 15 May 2006.</ref>
''[[Reign of Fire (film)|Reign of Fire]]'' was Bale's first action [[star vehicle|vehicle]] and had, compared to all his previous work, an immense budget estimated at US$95,000,000.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0253556/business ''Reign of Fire''.] ''[[Internet Movie Database]]''.</ref> Bale entered into negotiations about starring in the film with reservations, but director [[Rob Bowman (filmmaker)|Rob Bowman]] convinced him to take the lead role.<ref name="Chavel">Chavel, Sean. [http://www.ugo.com/channels/filmTv/features/reignoffire/christianbale.asp "Interview with Christian Bale of Reign of Fire."] ''[[UGO|UnderGroundOnline]]''. Retrieved on 8 June 2006.</ref> Bale starred as Quinn Abercromby opposite [[Matthew McConaughey]]'s Denton Van Zan. Bale and McConaughey trained for their respective roles by [[boxing]] and working out.<ref name="Chavel" />
''[[Equilibrium (film)|Equilibrium]]'' was Bale's third film of 2002, costing US$20 million to produce but earning just over US$5 million worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=equilibrium.htm|title=Equilibrium (2002)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=13 April 2009}}</ref> In ''Equilibrium'', Bale played John Preston, an elite law enforcer in a [[dystopian]] society. ''Equilibrium'' featured a fictional [[martial art]] called [[Gun Kata]] that combined [[firearm|gunfighting]] with [[hand-to-hand combat]]. According to moviebodycounts.com, the character of John Preston has the third most on-screen kills in a single movie ever with 118, exactly half of the movie's total of 236.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moviebodycounts.com|title=Equilibrium Body Count|accessdate=15 September 2006|publisher= Movie Body Counts}}</ref>
After a year's hiatus, Bale returned in 2004 to play Trevor Reznik, the title character in the [[psychological thriller]] ''[[The Machinist]]''. Bale gained attention for his devotion to the role and for the lengths to which he went to achieve Reznik's emaciated, skeletal appearance. He went without proper rest for prolonged periods, and placed himself on a [[crash diet]] of generally coffee and apples,<ref name="RadioFree">{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Michael J.|url=http://movies.radiofree.com/interviews/themachi_christian_bale.shtml|title=Interviews Christian Bale, The Machinist|accessdate=5 May 2008|date=4 October 2004|publisher=Radio Free}}</ref> which reduced his weight by 63 pounds ({{convert|4|st|4|lb|kg|abbr=on|disp=s}}) in a matter of months.<ref name="IGN">{{cite web|last=Gilchrist|first=Todd|url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/557/557527p1.html|title=IGN Interviews Christian Bale|work=[[IGN]] FilmForce| publisher=[[News Corporation]]|date=15 October 2004|accessdate=15 October 2004}}</ref> By the end of filming Bale weighed only 121 pounds ({{convert|8|st|9|lb|kg|abbr=on|disp=s}}),<ref name="RadioFree"/> a transformation he described as "very calming mentally"<ref name="Movieweb">{{cite web|last=Topel|first=Fred|url=http://www.movieweb.com/news/NEHtLOKJ9zqXLO|title=Christian Bale talks The Machinist|date=15 October 2004|accessdate=5 May 2008|publisher=Movie Web}}</ref> and which drew comparisons to [[Robert De Niro]]'s alternate weight-gaining regimen for his role as [[Jake LaMotta]] in the 1980 film ''[[Raging Bull]]''.<ref name="New York Times">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/22/movies/22mach.html?_r=1&ex=1129953600&en=26674be522fa7098&ei=5083&partner=Rotten%20Tomatoes|title=Insomnia and Then Emaciation; Now Paranoia Takes Its Turn|last=Holden|first=Stephen|date=22 October 2004|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=20 April 2009}}</ref> Bale claimed that he had not worked for a period of time before he was cast in the film. "...I just hadn't found scripts that I'd really been interested in. So I was really dying for something to arrive. Then when this one did, I just didn't want to put it down. I finished it and, upon the kind of revelation that you get at the end, I immediately wanted to go back and re-visit it, to take a look at what clues I could have gotten throughout".<ref name="stephenwales">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/arts/sites/themes/film/christian_bale_machinist.shtml|title=Christian Bale interview: The Machinist (2004)|last=Applebaum|first=Stephen|work=[[BBC Wales]]|publisher=[[BBC Films]]|accessdate=20 April 2009}}</ref> ''The Machinist'' was a low-budget production, costing roughly US$5 million to produce, and was given only a limited US release. It was well received, with the review tallying website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reporting that 75% of the critics' reviews tallied were positive.<ref>{{cite web | title = The Machinist (2004) | work = Rotten Tomatoes | publisher = IGN Entertainment | url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/machinist/ | accessdate =24 March 2008}}</ref>
Bale, an admirer of [[Hayao Miyazaki]]'s ''[[Spirited Away]]'',<ref name="Morris" /> was then cast as the voice of the title character, [[Wizard Howl|Howl]], in the English language [[dubbing (filmmaking)|dub]] of the Japanese director's [[fantasy film|fantasy]] [[anime]] adventure ''[[Howl's Moving Castle (film)|Howl's Moving Castle]]'', an adaptation of [[Diana Wynne Jones]]'s [[Howl's Moving Castle|children's novel]]. Its gross in the US was US$4,711,096, a fraction of its worldwide gross (US$235,184,110).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=howlsmovingcastle.htm|title=Howl's Moving Castle (2005)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=13 April 2009}}</ref>
===Batman: 2005âpresent=== It was reported that Bale had previously auditioned for the role of [[Dick Grayson|Robin]] in ''[[Batman Forever]]'' (1995) and later ''[[Batman & Robin (film)|Batman and Robin]]'' (1997), but lost out to [[Chris O'Donnell]]. However, this rumor was later dispelled by Bale himself in a magazine interview in 2008.<ref>''ShortList'', issue 42, page 28, 17 July 2008.</ref> In 2004, after completing filming for ''[[The Machinist]]'', Bale won the coveted role of [[Batman]] and his alter ego Bruce Wayne in [[Christopher Nolan]]'s ''[[Batman Begins]]'', a [[reboot (continuity)|reboot]] of the [[Batman in film|Batman film series]]. Bale beat out [[Jake Gyllenhaal]], the closest competition for the role.<ref>Otto, Jeff. [http://movies.ign.com/articles/495/495335p1.html "David S. Goyer Talks Batman, Iron Man, Comics and More"] [[IGN]] ''FilmForce'', 27 February 2004, retrieved on 16 May 2006.</ref>
Still fresh off ''The Machinist'', it became necessary for Bale to bulk up to match Batman's muscular physique. He was given a deadline of six months to do this. Bale recalled it as far from a simple accomplishment: "...when it actually came to building muscle, I was useless. I couldn't do one push up the first day. All of the muscles were gone, so I had a real tough time rebuilding all of that."<ref name="IGN" /> With the help of a [[personal trainer]], Bale succeeded in meeting the deadline, gaining a total of {{convert|100|lb|kg|abbr=on}} in six months. He went from about 130 lbs to 230 lbs.<ref>Jordan, Sean. [http://www.femmefatales.com/?p=44 "Christian Bale: Belatedly Blabbing Pee Wee"] ''Femme Fatales'', July/August, 2005, retrieved on 16 May 2006.</ref> He then discovered that he had actually gained more weight than the director desired, and dropped his weight to 190 lbs by the time filming began.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies.about.com/od/batman/a/batmancb060805.htm|title=About.com interview |publisher=Movies.about.com|date=30 October 2009|accessdate=26 February 2010}}</ref>
Bale had initial concerns about playing Batman, as he felt more ridiculous than intimidating in the [[Batsuit]]. He dealt with this by depicting Batman as a savage beast.<ref name="IGN" /> To attain a deeper understanding of the character, Bale read various Batman comic books. He explained his interpretation of the young boy: "Batman is his hidden, [[demon]]ic rage-filled side. The creature Batman creates is an absolutely sincere creature and one that he has to control but does so in a very haphazard way. He's capable of enacting violence â and to kill â so he's constantly having to rein himself in." For Bale, the most gruelling part about playing Batman was the suit. "You stick it on, you get hot, you sweat and you get a headache in the mask," he said. "But I'm not going to bitch about it because I get to play Batman."<ref>Dawson, Angela. [http://www.azcentral.com/ent/movies/articles/0610bale10.html "Bale on Batman"] azcentral.com, 10 June 2005, retrieved on 16 May 2006.</ref> When promoting the film in interviews and public events, Bale retained an American accent to avoid confusion.<ref>Morales, Wilson. [http://www.blackfilm.com/20050610/features/christianbale.shtml "Batman Begins: An Interview with Christian Bale"]</ref>
''Batman Begins'' was released in the U.S. on 15 June 2005 and was a U.S. and international triumph for [[Warner Bros.]], costing approximately US$135 million to produce and taking in over US$370 million in returns worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=batmanbegins.htm|title=Batman Begins (2005)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=13 April 2009}}</ref> Bale earned the Best Hero award at the [[MTV Movie Awards 2006|2006 MTV Movie Awards]] for his performance.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/fashion/gay-cowboys-the-best-kissers/2006/06/04/1149359608529.html|title=Gay cowboys the best kissers|date=4 June 2006|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=13 April 2009}}</ref><!-- There is a whole body of text that covers critical perception of Batman Begins that had to be taken out because it cut the entire article off at this point for some reason. Iâm attempting to fix the problem.-->
Bale reprised his role as Batman in the ''Batman Begins'' sequel ''[[The Dark Knight (film)|The Dark Knight]]''. He trained in the [[Keysi Fighting Method]], and performed many of his own stunts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/film/article330481.ece|title=Christian's killer Keysi training|last=Maloney|first=Alison|date=11 October 2007|work=[[The Sun (newspaper)|The Sun]]|accessdate=13 April 2009}}</ref> ''The Dark Knight'' was released in the U.S. on 18 July 2008 and stormed through the box office, with a record-breaking $158.4 million in the U.S. in its first weekend.<ref>{{cite news|title= Dark Knight Sets Weekend Box-Office Record|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,386822,00.html|work=Foxnews.com|agency=Associated Press|date=21 July 2008}}</ref> It broke the $300 million barrier in 10 days, the $400 million mark in 18 days and the $500 million mark in 43 days, three new U.S. box office records set by the film.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Dark Knight Rewrites Box Office Record Books|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jIoMPprXFl4emMKV7YkA7XIACbGg|work=Google News|publisher=AFP|date=22 July 2008}}</ref> The film went on to gross over $1 billion at the box office worldwide, making it the fourth-highest grossing movie worldwide of all time, before adjusting for inflation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/world|title=Box Office Mojo â All Time Worldwide Box Office Grosses|publisher=Boxofficemojo.com|date=|accessdate=26 February 2010}}</ref>
It has been confirmed that Bale will star in the third projected movie in the rebooted franchise, ''[[The Dark Knight Rises]]'', which will be released on 20 July 2012,<ref>{{cite news|author=Ray Subers|title='Batman' Returns July 20, 2012|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|date=30 April 2010|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2747&p=.htm|accessdate=30 April 2010}}</ref> making Bale the actor who has played Batman more times than any other actor in feature film. Bale has given the same opinion as Nolan that, if the latter was forced to bring Robin into the films, he would never again play Batman; even though one of his favorite Batman stories, ''[[Batman: Dark Victory]]'', focuses on Robin's origin.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://batman.ugo.com/movies/batman_begins/bale.asp|title=UGO's World of Batman â Christian Bale interview for Batman Begins|publisher=[[UGO Networks]]}}</ref>
===2006â2009=== [[Image:Christian Bale - 002.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Close-up of Christian Bale's face.|Bale in 2008]] After ''Batman Begins'', Bale returned to appearing in independent films. He was cast as one of the two leads in the [[South Los Angeles|South Central]] [[David Ayer]]-helmed crime drama ''[[Harsh Times]]'', co-starring with [[Freddy Rodriguez]] and [[Eva Longoria]]. Bale played Jim Luther Davis, a grim [[War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)|Afghanistan War]] veteran afflicted with [[post-traumatic stress disorder]], approached by the [[Department of Homeland Security]] and hired as a federal agent. ''Harsh Times'' premiered at the 2005 [[Toronto International Film Festival]] and had a wide release on 10 November 2006.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2005-07-26-blanchett-toronto_x.htm|title=Blanchett joins Toronto festival lineup|date=26 July 2005|work=[[USA Today]]|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=13 April 2009}}</ref>
[[Terrence Malick]] directed ''[[The New World (film)|The New World]]'', a [[period piece]] inspired by the stories of [[Pocahontas]], and Bale was cast as [[John Rolfe]]. He shared the screen with [[Colin Farrell]] and [[Q'Orianka Kilcher]], who played John Smith and Pocahontas. The majority of screen time was devoted to Farrell and Kilcher; Bale was a secondary character, and only appeared during the last third of the film. The film was a failure at the U.S. box office and its worldwide total (US$29,506,437) fell short of turning a profit (the production budget was placed at US$30 million).<ref>{{cite web|title=The New World at Box Office Mojo|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=newworld.htm}}</ref>
In 2006, Bale took on four projects. ''[[Rescue Dawn]]'', by German filmmaker [[Werner Herzog]], had him playing U.S. [[Fighter aircraft|Fighter]] pilot [[Dieter Dengler]], who has to fight for his life after being shot down while on a mission during the [[Vietnam War]]. Bale left a strong impression on Herzog, with the director complimenting his acting abilities: "I find him one of the greatest talents of his generation. We made up our own minds long before he did ''[[Batman (film series)|Batman]]''."<ref>[https://www.femalefirst.co.uk/movies/movie-news/Christian+Bale-15606.html "Herzog Hails Bale"] ''Female First'', 24 March 2006, retrieved on 17 May 2006.</ref> {{quote box|width=30%|align=left|quote="I kind of like movies where I just get to just be dirty and crawling in the mud, "Rescue Dawn" it was all very primordial stuff, and with this one it was all about wearing the same clothes day after day and getting sweaty and dirty and sun exposure, and it's meant to be like that; Westerns are meant to be dirty, they shouldn't be all nice and clean. ====''Terminator Salvation'' incident==== In July 2008, Bale flew into an angry tirade on the sets of ''[[Terminator Salvation]]'', while filming in [[New Mexico]].<ref name="CT_tirade">{{cite news|url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/chi-christian-bale-freak-out-090203-ht,0,1676527.story|title=Christian Bale Freak Out|accessdate=4 February 2009|date= 3 February 2009|work=chicagotribune.com|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> In February 2009, the audio recording of the incident was released.<ref>http://www.aolcdn.com/tmz_audio/020209_christianbale.mp3</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4508022/Christian-Bale-rant-Full-transcript.html|title=Christian Bale rant: Full transcript|accessdate=4 February 2009|date=4 February 2009|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|location=London}}</ref> The tirade was directed at [[Shane Hurlbut]], director of photography for the film. According to Bale, Hurlbut had, for the second time, ruined his concentration by walking onto the set during a scene.<ref name="CT_tirade"/><ref name="in_tirade"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2009/02/02/bale-went-ballistic|title=Bale Went Ballistic|accessdate=3 February 2009|last=|first=|coauthors=|date=2 February 2009|work=|publisher=[[TMZ.com]]}}</ref> The recording is of a highly agitated Bale directing profanities at Hurlbut, threatening and belittling him, and finally threatening to quit the film if Hurlbut repeated his offence without being fired for it.<ref name="in_tirade">{{cite news |url= http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/bale-turns-american-psycho-with-expletiveladen-tantrum-on-set-1544988.html|title= Bale turns American psycho with expletive-laden tantrum on set|accessdate=4 February 2009|date=4 February 2009|author= Adams, Guy|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent News and Media Limited|location=London}}</ref> It was reported that Warner film executives sent the tape to the insurer of the film in case Bale decided to quit the movie.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/sfgate/detail?blogid=7&entry_id=35382|title=Costar Defends Bale Blowout|accessdate=4 February 2009|date=3 February 2009|work=SFGate.com; [[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher= [[Hearst Corporation|Hearst Communications, Inc.]] | first=Laurie | last=Isola}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[E! Online]]'', assistant director and producer of ''Terminator Salvation'', Bruce Franklin, said it was an isolated incident. "If you are working in a very intense scene and someone takes you out of your groove ... It was the most emotional scene in the movie ... [A]nd for him to get stopped in the middle of it. He is very intensely involved in his character. He didn't walk around like that all day long. It was just a moment and it passed," Franklin said.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/uberblog/b81964_christian_bale_f-bombs_terminator_set.html|title= Christian Bale F-Bombs Terminator Set; "It Was Just a Moment", Assistant Director Says|accessdate=3 February 2009|last=Finn|first= Natalie|coauthors=|date=2 February 2009|work=|publisher=[[E! Online]]}}{{dead link|date=August 2010}}</ref>
Actors [[Whoopi Goldberg]] and [[Terry Crews]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29001920/|title=Whoopi Goldberg defends Christian Bale|accessdate=6 February 2009|date=3 February 2009|publisher=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/lifestyle/chi-0204-ft-christian-balefeb04,0,1061501.story|title=Whoopi Goldberg won't pile on against Christian Bale|accessdate=4 February 2009|date=4 February 2009|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]}}</ref> directors [[Darren Aronofsky]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7871743.stm|title=Wrestler director supports Bale|accessdate=6 February 2009|date=5 February 2009|publisher=BBC|work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> and [[Ron Howard]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.listal.com/video/101546510|title=Ron Howard comments on Christian Bale meltdown|publisher=Listal.com|date=5 February 2009|accessdate=26 February 2010}}{{dead link|date=August 2010}}</ref> as well as ''[[Ain't It Cool News]]'' website creator [[Harry Knowles]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Snead|first=Elizabeth|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/thedishrag/2009/02/harry-knowles-d.html|title=Harry Knowles defends Christian Bale's ugly outburst?|accessdate=5 February 2009|date=4 February 2009|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> have also publicly defended Bale's actions, some of them citing the practice that crew members are to remain still while the camera is rolling. The incident also inspired experimental band [[The Mae Shi]] to write the song, "[[R U Professional]]", which features samples from the recording;<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.boingboing.net/2009/03/17/bb-video-the-mae-shi.html|title=BB Video: The Mae Shi are "Professionals" â Boing Boing|publisher=www.boingboing.net|accessdate=2 July 2009|last=|first=}}</ref> similarly, [[Lucian Piane]]'s remix "[[Bale Out]]" is composed almost entirely of audio from the incident. [[Stephen Colbert]] parodied the incident on the 4 February 2009 episode of ''[[The Colbert Report]]'', in which guest [[Steve Martin]] repeatedly walked in front of the camera and was berated by Colbert.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ccinsider.comedycentral.com/2009/02/05/stephen-colbert-goes-christian-bale-on-steve-martin|title=Stephen Colbert goes Christian Bale on Steve Martin|publisher= [[Comedy Central]]|date= 5 February 2009|accessdate=5 February 2009}}</ref> The incident was re-enacted on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', with ''[[Inside the Actor's Studio]]'' host [[James Lipton]] giving performances of both Bale and the crewmember.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://backseatcuddler.com/2009/02/05/james-lipton-mocks-christian-bales-tirade-on-conan-obrien|title=James Lipton Mocks Christian Bale's Tirade on Conan OâBrien|publisher=Backseat Cuddler|accessdate=2 May 2010|last=|first=}}</ref> [[Ocean's Three and a Half|An episode]] of the animated comedy series ''[[Family Guy]]'' also mixed in the voice of [[Peter Griffin]] interacting with Bale and reacting to Bale's comments as if they were directed at him to comedic effect.
After remaining silent for most of the week, Bale gave a public apology on 6 February 2009, to a Los Angeles radio station, [[KROQ-FM|KROQ]]. He stated that the outburst was "inexcusable" and that it was motivated by the day's shooting intensity.<ref name="kroq">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Movies/02/06/bale.apology/index.html|title= Bale apologizes for 'Terminator' tantrum|last=Duke|first=Alan|date=6 February 2009|publisher=[[CNN|CNN: Showbiz/Movies]]|accessdate=13 April 2009}}</ref> Bale said he "acted like a punk", and that he and Hurlbut talked after the incident and "resolved this completely".<ref name="bbcnews20090206">{{cite news|last=BBC News staff|title=Actor Bale speaks out over rant|quote= Film star Christian Bale has called a US radio station to apologize for a tirade which was leaked onto the internet, calling it "inexcusable"|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=BBC|date=6 February 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7875756.stm|accessdate=6 February 2009}}</ref> Bale acknowledged that the two worked together for several hours after the incident, and ''"at least a month after that... I've seen a rough cut of the movie and he has done a wonderful job. It looks fantastic"''.<ref name="bbcnews20090206" />
